channel.title: ENSH 201 Webzine Template
channel.description: The official template for ENSH 201 students.

item.title: ENSH 201 Webzine
item.dc:creator: twelch
item.content:encoded:
If you wanted a clone of the Default Blank Site template you are in the right place.

However, if an instructor has requested that you clone a specific template then you have not successfully completed the process and need to take some corrective action.

It might be a good idea to print or jot down the following steps. These steps will help you delete this site and correctly clone the one requested by your instructor.

  • Delete this site. You can do this in the admin panel for this site, in the Tools menu item and the Delete Site submenu item.
  • Go to https://opened.ca/wp-signup.php and clone the template required by your instructor making sure to click on the thumbnail image below the template name. Make sure there is a white check mark on the thumbnail image before proceeding. (See the example below, but select the template your instructor has required).

That should get you on your way. Have an excellent term!

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: twelch
item.content:encoded: Here is the place where your Webzine team can post its mission statement.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A stock photo of a bookshelf.

item.title: Current Issue
item.dc:creator: rebeccahalliday
item.content:encoded: Here is where your Webzine team can post a description of its current issue.

item.title: Contributors
item.dc:creator: rebeccahalliday
item.content:encoded: This is where your Webzine team can include its individual contributor bios and photos. You can insert photos of yourselves or use illustrations, pet photos or photos with avatars: just be consistent. You can also assign team members titles like Editor-in-Chief (or not). Bios should be ~ 100 to 150 words.

item.title: This is a sample post.
item.dc:creator: rebeccahalliday
item.content:encoded:
You can use the Posts option in the Dashboard to add new posts. Each feature article can take the form of one post.

The posts should be consistent in format and layout and should combine both text and photographs. Take time to experiment with the different text and visual elements that you can add to create a consistent, polished look for the posts.

Using photographs (this is a heading within a post)

Remember that all photographs or other visual elements need to be licensed under Creative Commons or otherwise be free to use (e.g. stock photos from sites such as Pexels or Unsplash). The formatting of the site names is an example of how to add a hyperlink: highlight the text and click on the Link icon.

You can also do a Google Image Search that filters for images that are licensed under Creative Commons. Under the Tools menu, click on Usage Rights and then check Creative Commons licenses. Double check the image source to confirm that the image is indeed available for public use.

One more note (this is another heading within a post)

Webzine teams should also include a comment form at the bottom of each post. To do this, add a block and, under the Theme options, choose the Comments Form. You might have to select Browse All first.

item.dc:creator: rebeccahalliday
